scenario:
Amazon's cloud computing unit, AWS, remains the largest in the world and is growing at a solid pace, with revenue up 19% in the fourth quarter. The company is investing heavily in AI, with a $100 billion capex budget this year, and has developed its own AI chips to give it a cost and efficiency advantage. Amazon's consumer business is also growing, with AI helping third-party sellers and consumers find items, and the company's high-margin advertising services business is performing well.

e.l.f. Beauty has been a growth story in the consumer goods space, but hit a snag last quarter due to weak industry trends and a potential TikTok ban. However, the company will see expanded shelf space this spring at Target and Walgreens, and has a big opportunity in skincare and international market expansion. e.l.f. trades at a forward P/E ratio of 19 times and a PEG of under 0.4, making it undervalued.

Philip Morris International has become a growth stock in the defensive tobacco industry, driven by its smokeless portfolio, including Zyn nicotine pouches and Iqos heated-tobacco system. Zyn has seen a 46% surge in volume last quarter, and the company is looking to launch Iqos in the U.S. after buying back its U.S. rights. Philip Morris has a strong growth outlook, with a forward P/E of 21 times and a PEG of 0.4 times.
